content: Modern supply chain management utilizes network analysis to optimize the flow of goods from manufacturers to consumers.
Network optimization reduces costs, improves delivery times, and enhances supply chain resilience.
Supply chain networks are modeled as complex adaptive systems where nodes represent facilities and edges represent transportation links or business relationships.
Hub-and-spoke configurations enable economies of scale but create potential single points of failure.
Direct shipping networks offer greater flexibility and resilience at the cost of higher per-unit transportation expenses.
Disruptions at tier-two suppliers can propagate forward through multi-tier networks to affect multiple downstream manufacturers.
Companies employ network visualization tools to gain visibility into extended supply networks beyond direct suppliers.
Supply chain network optimization requires balancing competing objectives such as cost minimization and service level maximization.
